awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Testing Models of Representation and Institutional Design in the State Courts' Consideration of Inequality
awd_abstract_narration: This project aims to create a new database of judicial decisions, to measure all policies relevant to inequality in a dozen or so policy domains, in all 50 states since 1971, and to test a series of conjectures about the conditions under which the state supreme courts act to mitigate or aggravate inequality. In particular, the project will use statistical analyses to test the hypothesis that the preferences of a state's citizenry on matters of inequality affect supreme court decisions. We further expect that this relationship depends on the methods used to select and retain judges in the state. Because the project's timeframe encompasses the rise of interest group involvement and television advertising in judicial election, the project will also investigate how the increasing politicization of judicial elections has affected judicial responsiveness to public opinion.  Overall, the analysis will be able to determine whether greater judicial accountability results in greater responsiveness to the mass public and/or to organized interests. Thus, this study will shed important new light on the causes of social, political, legal, and economic inequality in the states of the United States.

por.por_cntn:
The supreme courts of the 50 American states are extremely important policy-making institutions when it comes to policies affecting political, legal, economic, and social inequality in the U.S. From school finance disputes to the rights of employees and employers, these courts are in fact the “courts of last resort” for a vast array of disputes over inequality in the American states.

 These courts vary enormously, in virtually every conceivable way. Some courts routinely rule in favor of greater equality; other courts rarely do so. The same can be said of individual justices: some regularly cast votes in favor of greater equality, others rarely do so.

 Our project was designed to examine the policy-making activities of these courts and justices and to attempt to account for the variability in their decisions. Our most important conclusion is that many if not most of these courts rarely conflict with the dominant political institutions in their states. In many respects, these institutions are part of the dominant “governing coalition” in the state, meaning that their policies are rarely out-of-alignment with the state’s dominant ideology and with the preferences of the court’s constituents. Because that is so, the so-called counter-majoritarian capacity of these institutions—their ability to serve as a check on the more political branches of state governments—is limited indeed. The popular image of state supreme courts as protectors of “underdogs” (or “have-nots”) must, according to our analysis, be entirely recast. Some courts seem to perform this role; most, however, do not.
